comments:
I'm trying to open my old workspace with M9, but eclipse fails.
Error message:
JVM terminated. Exit code=1
/home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java
-cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main
-os linux
-ws gtk
-arch x86
-showsplash /home/dirk/eclipse/eclipse -showsplash 600
-exitdata /home/dirk/eclipse/eclipse -exitdata 498016
-vm /home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java
-vmargs
-cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main 

Command line used to start eclipse:
[dirk@zappws010 eclipse]$ eclipse -vm /home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.help.internal.ui.HelpActionSet
 
When I start M9 with an empty workspace, it starts without a problem.
The error message about the Action Set is also the only thing I can see in the
workspace/.metadata/.log file:
!SESSION May 24, 2004 12:03:45.198
---------------------------------------------eclipse.buildId=I200405211200
java.version=1.4.2_01
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86, WS=gtk, NL=en_US
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui 4 4 May 24, 2004 12:03:45.199
!MESSAGE Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.help.internal.ui.HelpActionSet

Is there a <timestamp>.log file in /home/dirk/eclipse/configuration?

Also, try running with:

cd /home/dirk/eclipse
/home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java -cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar
org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -data <your M8 workspace location>

Does it show a more detailed message?

Retried same scenario with RC1, same problem.
There is no configuration/<timestamp>.log when running as
eclipse -vm /home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java
but there is more debug output:

Unable to restore editor - no editor descriptor for id:
org.eclipse.jdt.ui.CompilationUnitEditor
Unable to restore editor - no editor descriptor for id:
org.eclipse.jdt.ui.CompilationUnitEditor
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.help.internal.ui.HelpActionSet
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaActionSet
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.jdt.ui.JavaElementCreationActionSet
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.jdt.debug.ui.JDTDebugActionSet
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.jdt.junit.JUnitActionSet
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.jdt.ui.A_OpenActionSet
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.jdt.ui.CodingActionSet
Unable to find Action Set: org.eclipse.jdt.ui.SearchActionSet


When running as
/home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java -cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar
org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -data /home/dirk/workspace
there is a <timestamp>.log, which I attached.

Created an attachment (id=11585)
Error log for this bug

Error log when starting RC1 with
/home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java -cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar
org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -data /home/dirk/workspace

where /home/dirk/workspace is a workspace which (still) works with M8.

Please disregard comments #2 and #3, those were from the platform edition
instead of the SDK edition :( Sorry!
Actual behaviour: RC1 starts fine with the old workspace, but crashes when
opening the java perspective. Starting with 'eclipse -vm
/home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java' gives no more error message, starting with
'/home/dirk/j2sdk1.4.2_01/bin/java -cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar
org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -data /home/dirk/workspace' gives this error log:

!SESSION Jun 04, 2004 11:57:15.133 ---------------------------------------------

There should be nothing in the workspace that affects Eclipse's ability to find
classes. All relevant data related to class loading is in the configuration area.

"RC1 starts fine with the old workspace, but crashes when opening the java
perspective." 

1) What do you mean by "starts fine"? Is there a perspective currently selected?
Which one? If basic SWT classes canot be found, I could not imagine how anything
would possibly work.

2) Also, what do you mean by "crashes when opening the java perspective". What
happens (error dialogs, UI glitches, process exits, etc)? Thanks.

3) Do you have write access to the install location? If so, could you rename the
directory called "configuration" inside your Eclipse install to something else
and try running again? Otherwise, it should be under a .eclipse directory in
your home dir.

Last request: please dele
Please ignore the last line in my comment above.

No further information from originator. Please reopen if you can reproduce the
problem with 3.0 final. In that case, we would need answers for the questions
asked above. Thanks.

I only today had the opportunity to try the 3.0 release version. I can't get it
to work. Detailed steps:
- I removed every trace of the previous eclipse version, including removing the
old workspace.
- I redownloaded the latest Java RunTime from Sun
(j2re-1_4_2_05-linux-i586.bin). I installed it in my home directory
(/home/dirk/j2re1.4.2_05).
- I downloaded the 3.0 release build (eclipse-SDK-3.0-linux-gtk.zip) and
installed it in my home directory (/home/dirk/eclipse).
- I verified that the java runtime is in my path ('which java' gives
'/home/dirk/j2re1.4.2_05/bin/java), JAVA_HOME is set to /home/dirk/j2re1.4.2_05
 and CLASSPATH is empty.

I start eclipse by going to ~/eclipse and executing './eclipse'. Eclipse starts
with the spash and then shows the welcome screen. I click the workbench icon,
and the workbench opens in the Resource perspective (answer to Question 1).
So far so good.
Then I try to open another perspective, for instance the Java perspective, by
selecting in the menu window - open perspective - java and eclipse exits. I get
the error dialog as specified in the original problem description (the one with
'JVM terminated. Exit code=1' but with different paths reflecting the current
situation). (answer to Question 2)
I tried all perspectives (cvs, java, java browsing, team synchronizing) but they
all fail in the same way.

I then tried to start eclipse with the command line as specified in comment #1
(java -cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -data
/home/dirk/workspace) and I got a similar error log as the one specified in
comment #4 (classloader not finding org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.IDEApplication).
However, I was able to fix this problem by adding '-os linux -ws gtk' to the
command line, after which I just got a 'Trace/breakpoint trap' message when
trying to open a workspace (so in fact the exact same behaviour as when starting
eclipse with './eclipse' except for the Trace/breakpoint trap error message
instead of an error dialog). Output from the command line in this case:
[dirk@zappws010 eclipse]$ java -cp /home/dirk/eclipse/startup.jar
org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main -data /home/dirk/workspace -os linux -ws gtk
Trace/breakpoint trap

I then tried to add the '-debug' flag to the command line, but except for the
usual startup messages, no other information was output.

I tried removing the /home/dirk/eclipse/configuration directory several times,
but to no avail. (answer to Question 3) There is no .eclipse directory in my
home directory, so I did not try removing anything there.

There is no error log in the configuration directory in any of the cases (except
for the time I started it without the -os linux -ws gtk parameters).

Since the current installation does not have access to my old workspace, there
is indeed nothing in that workspace that causes this behaviour.

I do have time the next 2 weeks to help solve this problem.

Googling around, I could find that this may be related to incorrectly built
libraries. What is your distro? Anything unusual in your setup?

This seems to be triggered by some SWT API usage that started to be used on M9.
Do you remember the latest build you used that did not show this problem?

I guess this belongs to SWT.

Rafael, why is SWT involved at all in the discussion?  I don't see it anywhere 
in the stack traces?

I believe we can disregard those stack traces. Dirk, can you confirm that when
starting with an empty workspace log (located at <workspace>/.log) no entries
are added to it in your test case? Could you also please answer the questions
asked in comment 9? Thanks.

The reason I suspect SWT is involved (as a victim, not as the culprit<g>) is
that the user faces a hard crash when doing a UI interaction (changing
perspectives). Also, the only output the user gets is: "Trace/breakpoint trap".
I could find several occurrences to posts where people reported having problems
like this, many involving GTK libraries. Since we (Platform/Core) do not rely on
native libraries (other than those used by the JRE itself), have no expertise on
Linux/GTK to research this problem further, and due to the nature of the
problem, I thought SWT would be a better home for this bug (even if to close it
as WORKSFORME).

I have a RedHat 9 distro, with the Ximian (now Novell) desktop installed. I use
the Ximian updater (Red-Carpet) to keep my distribution up-to-date.
As far as I know, there is nothing strange about my installation. I haven't
built anything from source, it's all just standard (released) libraries.
The problems did start with the M9 release, I can run M8 without problems (in
fact I'm still using it now).

As for versions, my gtk+ is version 2.3.2.

I guess I can try to build eclipse from source and see if that makes the problem
go away... Assuming I can get it to build ofcourse :)

As for the log, there is no .log in my workspace/.metadata directory. There is a
.lock file which stays behind (presumably because eclipse crashed).

Dirk, can you confirm your GTK+ version?  What is the output of
'rpm -qa | grep -i gtk' ?

The 2.3.x series of GTK+ is the unstable development branch from before GTK+ 2.4
which is the current stable.  RH9 ships with GTK+ 2.2.1 which we have also
tested against.  I would like to make sure you're actually using a stable
version of the GTK+ libraries.

I'm positive it's version 2.3.2. pkg-config says so, rpm says so, red-carpet
says so and the filename is libgtk-x11-2.0.so.0.302.0. So I'm pretty sure it's
2.3.2 ;-)

I'm not sure why I have a development version, must be because of the Ximian
desktop I have installed...

I tried rebuilding everything from source (which actually took me a little while
to figure out; building SWT for the first time isn't exactly straightforward), I
copied the SWT libs over my existing installation, still the same problem. I
then recompiled the eclipse application (just the executable) with the new libs,
still the same problem. I then recompiled the entire eclipse SDK (just for kicks
really) and ofcourse still the same problem.

I then downloaded the Motif version of 3.0, and it runs without a hitch. So I'll
continue to use the Motif version until I have a chance to reinstall my system.

Dirk, I am going to close this one, since your setup is not supported. Feel free
to reopen it if after installing a stable GTK+ version, the same problem still
happens.

Thanks for the insight, Billy.
